text: ladies and Gentlemen please welcome to the stage senior vice president of Amazon web services Andy
[Music] [Applause] [Music]
[Applause] jasse thank you for being here and it is
my privilege to welcome you to the second annual AWS reinvent
conference for those of you who are coming for the first time welcome for
those of you coming back for the second year in a row welcome back reinvent is a
different type of Technology conference it's not a sales and marketing conference it's a learning conference
and what we're hoping for is that you learn more about AWS you learn more about the cloud you learn about what a
lot of your peers are doing in the cloud and then you take that information back to your own companies and use it and
make action out of it to improve your own businesses we have 9,000 people here in
the next few days and about the same amount watching this via streaming from 57
countries and the type of companies that are represented here is pretty diverse
it's roughly a third startups a third midsize companies and a third large
Enterprises they'll be over 175 sessions that will be taught many of which will
be taught by partners and customers there'll be 38 different office hour segments taught by hundreds of AWS
Engineers here and then there'll be boot camps that many of you signed up for certification and training and then of
course on Thursday night the AWS replay party which should be pretty
festive so we started working on AWS a little over 10 years ago and we
we've been in the market now for 7 and a half years and even though if you look at the stage of our platform today and
the robustness of what's available it's night and day from when we started we still think about ourselves as seven
years young and that's because we have so much more coming for you guys our customers in the next few years and yet
in the interm what we've done is we've built a very robust fully featured
technology infrastructure platform that has great breadth of services and depth the features within those services and
so we've got compute Services most people know elastic compute cloud or ec2
we have a number of storage Services we have object storage an Amazon S3 or simple storage service we have a block
store an elastic Block store we have a backup and archival storage solution in Amazon Glacier we have multiple database
Services we have a relational database service called Amazon relational database service or RDS that comes in
MySQL or Oracle or SQL Server flavors we have a very high throughput very low
latency non-relational database service in Dynamo DB and then we have a very
broad array of app services that range from Amazon redshift which is a data
warehouse service to a Content distribution Network in cloudfront to a big data analytics service and elastic
map ruce to queuing to Notifications to email to search to work
flow to transcoding to caching to mobile push a very broad array of app services
so it's easier for you to get your applications built quickly without having to reinvent the wheel and then we
have a number of deployment options for you for those that want to use the apis the command line they can for those that
want to do nothing but use a dropin container where you upload a file we automatically provision the instances
the load balancing the auto scaling the monitoring we have have that too in the form of elastic beanock which comes in a
number of programming languages and then we have a lot of people services that we've added in the last few years as
customers have asked us to do so so we have a premium support capability for those that want oneon-one technical
account management we have a Professional Services team that goes in and helps you figure out which workloads
should move first to the cloud and then actually will help you implement the first couple and then we have certification and training so a very
broad robust technology infrastructure platform form that has bread of services and then a lot of depth within those
services and I think what we would say outside of the operational performance and the security of the platform the
first seven and a half years the thing that as a team we're collectively most proud of is the pace that we've been
able to innovate on behalf of you guys our customers and just for perspective in 2010 we launched what we considered
61 significant Services of features in 2011 that number was 8 two in 2012 that
number was 159 and this year just year to date through today that numbers 235 with a
lot more coming in the next six weeks so the pace of innovation is accelerating in
AWS we have a broad Geographic footprint and the way to think about geography in
AWS is that we have these constructs which are regions and a region is a physical place in the world where we
have multiple data centers are availability zones and we have nine regions in AWS today we have a region on
the east coast of the United States two on the west coast of the United States we have regions in Europe in Singapore
in Tokyo in Sydney in Brazil and then we have a government only region called
govcloud which is for itar compliant workloads natural US citizens requirements and then we have 25
availability zones across those nine regions and then we have 46 Edge
locations for our content distribution Network cloudfront so a very broad Geographic footprint and we're not close
to being done adding here we have hundreds of thousands of
customers in over 190 countries and it's a very Broad and diverse group it ranges
from some of the most successful startups like Pinterest and Dropbox and Spotify and Instagram and
Airbnb to large Enterprises like Netflix and Sam and Nokia and DOW Jones General
Electric and Phillips fizer and Bristol Meers squib and into it and sunor to the
public sector where we have over 600 government agencies worldwide using AWS
and over 2400 academic institutions it's a very Broad and diverse customer base
that's growing very quickly every day and we also have a very vibrant and
large ecosystem of Partners that are helping customers build on top of AWS we
always believe from the start of AWS that having a a vibrant ecosystem was going to be very strategic because it's
what customers want customers want help figuring out how to move into the cloud and they want to be able to run the same
software they've been running forever but just on our technology infrastructure platform so we have
thousands of systems integrators that have built practices and are are helping companies move to AWS from very large
ones like Cap Gemini and cognizant and Accenture and wiipro and emphasis and boo Allen to some of the more upand
cominging Regional ones that have grown up in the cloud like second watch and data loose and Cloud pack and we have a
very large number thousands of independent software vendors are isvs as well ranging from sap and Oracle and
Adobe and Autodesk and in4 and Sage these are all designed to allow you to
run the software you want to be able to run on top of aws's platform and then about a year and a half ago we launched
something called AWS Marketplace and this allows isvs to get more visibility
across AWS customers and customers can buy this software which is already built to work on top of AWS and they can
deploy it in one click and have all the deployment happen behind the scenes or they can deploy it at their Leisure
later on we have over 25 product categories in the marketplace we have over 1100 products this business has
grown over 700% just since the beginning of the year it's one of the fastest growing businesses in
AWS and as such we have growing our business very dramatically over the last
several years and it continues to grow at a very rapid Pace this is Gartner's
latest infrastructure is a service magic quadrant which came out about two months ago and you can see that AWS is in that
top right corner and the other 14 providers are kind of clustered in the middle to to bottom left and Gartner's
assessment is that AWS has more than five times the server capacity deployed
than the other 14 providers combined so we have a pretty significant leadership position that's
accelerating so why are so many companies big and small moving to the cloud so fast I think there are several
reasons the first question that companies will ask us whatever size they are is about sec
secy and and it should be their first
priority and that's because if you have customer data that matters your number
one priority as a company is making sure it's secure that's our number one priority too as a platform and what we
tell customers is that we use all the same strategies and tactics that Enterprise technology companies have
been using in in uh the security space for the last 30 years we have very strict
physical Access Control to our data centers we're very careful to make sure that our network is not intruded in any
way we're very disciplined about wiping our Hardware clean when customers abdicate resources we have all kinds of
software and systems that give you more control over who can access your resources and you can specify which
users and which functions and which services but what's also very
advantageous in using AWS is that we have such a large number of Enterprises and Public public sector companies who
care a lot about security who are constantly giving us inut and how they want to see us continue to evolve the
security features on our platform that everybody else in the platform gets to enjoy those improvements for free so
there's a real nice Network effect here where the more customers that end up on the AWS platform the more input we get
on features and security capabilities and then the better it is for everybody else cuz they get to they get to enjoy
those benefits for free by virtue of being on the same platform as all these others we also over the last number of
years have been asked by Enterprises and companies of all sizes to get
certifications to make it easier for them to feel comfortable deploying all their workloads in the cloud and so over
the last half a dozen years we've added these certifications that customers have told us mattered sock one and sock 2 p
uh ISO 27 01 we've made it our environment PCI Compliant customers can run Hippa
compliant workloads in AWS there's a number of federal certifications we've gotten as well ranging from fsma to fips
to itar to fedramp even in the media space where we had a number of our large
media customers who wanted to put their most secure Assets in our cloud and they
wanted us to go out and get the Motion Picture Association of America's highest security certification we went out and
got that because our customers told us it was important so as we hear things the customers say matter to them in this
space we'll continue to go out and get certifications I'm excited to introduce a new offering now in the security space
that's available today and that offering is called AWS cloud trail and what it is
is it's a service that logs all the API calls that you're making to your AWS
resources so it tells you who's making the API calls what they're asking to
have changed which resources are being changed and where those API calls are coming from and we store all that data
in S3 or you can archive it to Amazon Glacier if you prefer and it works in
conjunction with all the third-party logging tools that people use today things like Splunk and Sumo logic and
log l and this allows companies not only to run sophisticated security analysis
but also to better work their compliance and governance so this is an area that we've gotten a lot of feedback from
customers over time we're excited to offer today I think you can expect us to add more things to this service and
around this area over time customers are also moving to the cloud for availability and this is a
study that was just completed a week or two ago from nucleus research and what they did was they asked a bunch of AWS
customers what their availability was before they moved to AWS on premise and
then after they moved to AWS and what they found was that after
they moved to AWS they had 32% less downtime than when they were running it
on premise and that resonates with a lot of the feedback we've anecdotally gotten from our customers where they feel like
their availability has improved since they moved to AWS and we give them the type of architectures and infrastructure
where they can build in a fault tolerant way
so cost is often the conversation starter in people thinking about moving
to the cloud and there's a lot of pieces to cost when you think about what your
own infrastructure is and then you think about AWS so the First Advantage you get in the cloud is that if you don't have
to lay out all that capital in advance for servers and Data Centers before you know what the demand is going to be
that's a big advant anage to turn Capital expense into variable expense is very attractive to most companies and
then that variable expense is lower in AWS than what most companies can do on their own and that's because AWS is such
large scale at this point that we pass on that scale to our customers in the form of lower
prices there are multiple pricing models in AWS so you can optimize for what your
workloads requirements are the pricing model that most people know about is on demand and that's when you pay by the
hour you show up you use it when you stop using it you give it back to us and you stop paying for it but we also have
something called reserved instances that customers who have steady state workloads tend to run on and for with
reserved instances for a small upfront fee you can choose to reserve an instance for a year for three years and
then you pay roughly half the hourly cost of on demand and then we have a third construct called spot instances
and what we do is we take all our excess cap capacity at any one moment and we make it available in a spot market and
customers can make a maximum bid for those spot instances and if their bid is
higher than the market clearing price at any one time they get to run on those instances and if it's not they don't and
so for customers who have workloads that can afford to be interrupted or take time to complete it's a really
cost-effective way to use AWS and so what we find most of our big customers do is they take their steady state
workload they run those in reserved instances and then they fill in the rest of their capacity needs with either on demand or
spot depending on how fast they need to get that work done and how easily that workload is is able to be interrupted
and then the more you use AWS the less your costs are we have tiered and volume
pricing discounts for customers for those that are doing Big Data Center migrations or in the process of moving
everything to AWS they often will negotiate custom prices with us so a
great opportunity to save cost across the board in the cloud and in AWS and
the reason that we do this is it reflects a pricing philosophy we have
and we have a really interesting dynamic in our business where we have this virtuous cycle or Circle where the more
customers we have the more AWS usage it drives the more AWS usage the more
infrastructure we have to buy the more infrastructure we have to buy we get economies of scale from buying so much
with the economies of scale it lowers our infrastructure costs which allows us to reduce our prices which allows us to
drive more customers and spin that wheel and it turns out that you have opportunities to to spin that flywheel
faster as you have a larger ecosystem that helps customers move into the cloud
as you have a broad Global footprint as you add more services and features so customers can do more as you invent and
innovate in the infrastructure to lower your costs all those activities spin that wheel faster and it's one of the
reasons why you've seen us lower prices on 38 different occasions in the last
few years largely in the absence of any competitive pressure to do so and that's
because I've worked at Amazon for 16 years in every one of our businesses I
have never come across customers that have said I wish I could pay more and if you have a philosophy like Amazon
does and like AWS does that you start with the customer and everything works backwards from there and you know that
customers care about lower cost then you work hard to take cost out of your own cost structure and then pass that back
to customers in the form of lower prices we're so obsessed with trying to
save customers money that we do things like this which is our trusted advisor
program this is part of our premium support capability and what we do is we have a number of
ways that we can look at customers setup on top of AWS and try to recommend to
them when they may be doing something inefficient one of the things we do is we look at customers who are running
steady state workloads who are using on demand instead of reserved instances where they could save money or we look
at customers who have a bunch of idle instances where they're just wasting money and we proactively reach out to
customers and say hey do you know you can save money and this year alone we've
sent roughly a million of these notifications 700,000 of which have been
opened and acted on and that saved customers an on an annualized basis $140
million now I ask you how many technology companies proactively call up
their customers and say could you spend less money with them not too many but that's because we have a different
philosophy again we start with a customer and we move backwards from there and we're
trying to build a long-term relationship with customers and a business that Outlast all of
us even though cost is often what starts the conversation in the cloud what we
have seen as the top driver for companies moving to the cloud over time has been the ability to have increased
agility why does agility matter well in this day and age you're
at a huge competitive competitive disadvantage if you're not able to move fast you can look at startups that are
on this slide as an example that have moved into pretty stable areas and
radically disrupted those areas look at what Airbnb has done with hotels look at
what Spotify has done in the music space Dropbox with storage and Instagram with photos Uber in the taxi space these are
relatively stable businesses that have been really significantly disrupted Enterprises can't afford to be
slow anymore and yet if you talk to an engineer or an engineering leader in
Enterprise and you ask how long does it take to get a server to try an experiment or to put something into intg
we get answers that range from 6 to 25 weeks and typically it's between 10 to 18 weeks is the answer we get just think
about that it's demoralizing and as a company you just stop trying to invent
because you say why bother it's going to take so long to get a server if I have an idea and I want to try something and
God forbid it actually works how am I get going to get more servers anybody that does a lot of
invention will tell you that the two most important factors is number one being able to try a lot of experiments
and number two if those experiments fail and many should fail if you're pushing the envelope not having to live with the
collateral damage of those failed experiments in the cloud you can spin up
thousands of instances in minutes and then if those experiments
don't work out you can either reuse those instances for other experiments or
you can give them back to us and stop paying for them that's a huge difference a big difference in the
model and it means that you can do things like what are in the right column there you can instantly spin up Dev
environments or production environments or a two two pyte data warehouse and then spin it down or spin up a 5,000
node HPC cluster and spin it down it just changes what you can do and what you can
try but what it also does is two other things for your organization first it gives people in
the organization hope that if they come up with a new idea it might actually get implemented in a reasonable time frame
and then second it sense everybody across the entire organization from the senior most levels to the junior most
levels to spend some Cycles thinking about inventing because they know they have a chance that it could get
implemented we often get asked as the cloud has become so pervasive what's going to happen to our it teams and it
teams don't go away they of course work on value added activities on top of the
infrastructure instead of the undifferentiated heavy lifting of racking and stacking but a question I
hardly ever get asked and I think people should ask is how do I figure out a way
to get more of my employees thinking about new ideas and improvements for my
customers people who work at Enterprises want to invent every bit as much as
people who work at startups and they want to improve their customers experience every bit as much as people
who work at startups they've just been blocked by the infrastructure and the constraints that have been placed by them the cloud changes all of this the
cloud unleashes Innovation up and down the organization it's no longer a tiny group of people at the top who are
thinking about the new ideas you start to get the new ideas from everybody in the organization and what that does is
it allows you to hire better people because Builders want to actually work at a place where they know they have a chance to impact customer experience and
it's good for your end users it's good for your companies it's good for business so the cloud really is a win
across the board in that Dimension so now is it only speed of
deployment that gives you agility there's no doubt that if you're able to deploy ideas quicker you're going to be
much more agile however you still have to actually build the application that
meets whatever your idea was and if you have a way to not have to build all
those pieces yourself and to get from idea concept to that fast deployment we were just talking about faster that
gives you a lot of agility and so that's what you see a lot there's a lot of confusion sometimes about this point in
the cloud there are people who say oh the cloud that's that's just a data center I have data centers I know how to
run data centers I have colos and even though there's a huge difference in how you run data centers
at scale and if you get a chance in the next couple days I recommend going and seeing James Hamilton's presentations on
how AWS runs its data centers of scale because very different and I I think you'd find it worthwhile not
withstanding that the cloud and AWS are about a lot more than data centers even though we have a lot of data centers you
get the infrastructure software the hardware and the data center Services
wrapped neatly together in services like compute or storage or database and what
that means is that you don't have to spend the time or money writing or buying infrastructure software you don't
have to negotiate with Hardware vendors to buy Hardware wonder if you're getting a good price or if you bought too much
you don't have to set up and manage data centers and worry about power and network and bandwidth and operating
these heterogeneous environments you get those all as part of these compute storage and database
services but then it's about a lot more than just having services so a lot of people know ec2 and they know S3 and
they think well you know I can build a cloud I there are lots of clouds there's you know there are people who have
compute services there people who have object storage but a complete Cloud that
really takes a lot of the heavy lifting away from you has a lot more than compute and object storage it has block
storage it has backup and archival storage it has multiple flavors of relational database Services it has no
SQL database Services it has big data analytics Services it has data
warehouses has queuing it has notifications it has email it has workflow
it has monitoring it has a broad array of services and that's what you've seen AWS build over the last seven and a half
years but then once you've built those Services you can build services that
have very primitive capabilities but what customers really want is they want
these services to have real deep features and real deep capabilities that
allow them to use them for any way that they could imagine if you look at the pace of innovation in AWS
and you look at those 235 releases year-to date I was talking about earlier
that's what we're doing we're adding all kinds of features and capabilities in all these services and Amazon red shift
is a great example of that so Amazon red shift is our data warehouse service we announced it last year at reinvent and
then we opened it up for everybody in February of this year and in a little less than 9 months we have launched 26
new features in red shift alone and it took us a couple years to build red shift and then in the next 9 months we
built 26 features that continue to improve its capabilities almost exclusively informed by what you guys
our customers tell us matters so you get a broad array of services you get depth
of features within those services but also it's not enough if you have a global end user group of people that you
need to satisfy to be deployed in one or two reasons in one place of the world if you've got
a global business and you're building applications that need to serve a global end user base you need to be able to
deploy them globally and as AWS has nine regions with more coming you can do that
very quickly so when you think about agility having the ability to implement ideas
quickly and to deploy quickly is a game changer as we talked about earlier but it's also the ability to have have a
broad array of services that you can use with lots of features within those services and a global footprint to
deploy to all your end users that you need to satisfy that's what gives you agility and when you couple it with a
technology provider like AWS that already has a much larger amount of functionality than anybody else in the
space but is also iterating faster than anybody else you have a long-term ability to be more agile than anybody
else and than ever before so I want to give you uh the privilege
to meet our next speaker he works at an Enterprise that really gets agility they
have a culture of innovation unlike most Enterprises I've ever seen before it's very impressive and I want to introduce
the CEO of Business Services of sun Corp Jeff [Music]
Smith thank you
[Music] thanks Andy and good day to everybody
first I'll give you a quick snapshot of suncorp uh we're a diversified financial
services company operating in Australia and New Zealand we're the fifth largest bank we're the largest General
insurer the other piece is that our primary mission in life and purpose really is to price and manage risk on
behalf of our customers so our frame of reference is that lots of things go
wrong and then when you combine that with our overall business model it's quite complex we have multiple Brands we
have multiple products we have lots of systems different Technologies and when you combine complexity with lots of
things that go wrong it generates an awful lot of noise that makes it difficult to see
opportunity so our question was how could we sift through this noise and actually see the opportunity and go on
to great achievement and history has lots of great examples that demonstrate how people overcome great big problems
and there's three common characteristics that I've seen in a number number of these examples and the first is there's
no substitute for a good congestion of talent and the second is there typically
some technological achievement that's that's overcome and third and maybe most
important is a leadership culture that combines Clarity of purpose where you really understand the problem you're
going to solve along with passionate curiosity where you look beyond your own frame of reference and you overcome the
obstacles and you solve the problems so it's a great illustration of this and it deals with the painting of cars now many
of you may not know that cars were actually painted by hand up until the 1920s and it took 37 days to paint a car
multiple points of paint dry it and ready it for delivery the CEO of Dayton
engineering Laboratories compy compy which became Delco his name is Charles King and he
had solved many other problems before he had invented the electric starter for cars Freon refrigeration systems and he
was a gas at this and he challenged his engineer and said we've got to get better at this and they told him the
most we could ever get this down to 30 days so he looked beyond his own frame of references went many places and he
happened upon a jewelry store in New York City and he found lacquer dishes and he searched out the lacquer
producer was out of newers Jersey and he connected the lacquer producer with Dupont who was providing the paint and
they invented a paint thin enough that car could be spray painted a glossy enamel finish and dried in a few hours
so he took that example back to Dayton to his head of engineer took his head of engineer out to lunch and said I want
you to tell me again what's the best you can do and he said well it's going to be 30 days at that same time he had some
people go and steal that engineer's car and spray painted a lime green brought the engineer back and said
there's your car and the engineer said well that's impossible and he said that's your problem your job is to make the
impossible possible and he wrote a brief in the newspaper and it said something
like that preconception is a trap that theories are just the summaries of our past experiences and
not the limits of possibility and I have a saying at suncorp which is the wind screens a lot
bigger than the rearview mirror why should we be making our future judgments based on our past decisions
so the question is could we use that inspiration and and broaden our own
windscreen and look and see if we could stretch that limit of possibility and reimagine the IT
landscape so my CIO Matt benino and his set of infrastructure and cloud services
Terry pal they took it upon themselves to say we're going to go and make a mer very aggressive plan to move to the
cloud and then they very quickly realized quite astutely that when you start planning of what to move you spend
an equal amount of time with what can't be done and when you spend time talking about what can't be done that's waste so
they made the very bold and Brilliant decision to say we're going to move everything and we'll back ourselves to
have the talent and Leadership to figure out how to overcome those obstacles when they do come
up so the one lesson that we learned out of this is they very quickly honed in as
soon as they decided we're going to do everything we're going to we're going to we're going to focus on what goes first
and then how to accelerate it and the lesson we learned out of this is that the broader your vision the clearer your
purpose and so the other thing that we had to do was talk about well how do we actually accelerate this we've got the
technology breakthroughs we've got Amazon that's a tick but we have to provide the talent and the leadership to
do this and accelerate this so what we have going for us is we have an absolutely fantastic culture it's a
battle Harden culture built on the last six years of driving agile principles
and practices along with a very extensive graduate and and intern intake
over the last six years and some of the things that we hold dear to us in terms of our principles are Clarity over
certainty course correction over Perfection self-directed teams uh over
command and control and then our our agile practices which are around continuous delivery devops and
distributed agile and our distributed agile we have teams around the world that are connected 24x7 by Skype link
TVs where the work is assigned not on the role of the hierarchy they're in but on the skills and the gifts that they
bring to the party and we have a thing Innovation day that we use to reset our own aspirations we call it a FedEx day
and those days we copied it from a company called atasan we didn't Adit it in in Australia and the concept behind
that day is you can work with whoever you want you can solve any problem you want there's only two constraints the
first it's got to be done in 24 hours so bring your sleeping bags and your pillows the second is that you have to
have working software at the end of the day so we thought what if we use that day and Orient it toward Amazon and we
did and so using Amazon technology we had a FedEx day that that we called aome
API and we had 450 people from 10 locations in four countries 42 teams
that produced some phenomenal Solutions in the course of a day and Matt Wood from Amazon came down was in the the
judging panel and awarded the winners Kindles and the lesson that we really
learned out of this is that we constantly understate what our capabilities are to solve problems and
that the biggest constraint is never the constraint of of time or money it's generally the constraint of thought and
the key thing is how do we reset our aspirations to get over over the constraint of thought so finally so
where where are we Andy challenged us uh back at the end of July says you guys in 3 months can you set up a virtual
private Cloud virtual data center have production applications in place uh by November 1 and we took that challenge we
overcame all the technical hurdles to do it we overcame the non-technical hurdles like legal and risk and security and
procurement and the net of it is on October 30th we went live with Revenue generating online applications as well
as our bi applications and data streaming and we are now resetting our own aspirations for what's next and in
the course of that what we were able to do was create a very intimate emotional bond with Amazon where the the rising
Tide Is Lifting both ships and and my belief is both companies are benefiting outside of the commercial Arrangement so
my final advice to all of you here uh is that any problem can be solved so look
through your wind screen you know stretch your limit of possibility and opportunity and aim for Success not
Perfection because if you don't don't you'll lose the opportunity to learn new things in life thank you very
[Applause]
much thanks Jeff super impressed with what Sun Corp has done this quickly it's very
impressive entrepreneurial culture for an
Enterprise so just a reminder and what the benefits of the cloud
are you get to trade Capital expense for variable expense you get a lower variable expense than what you can do on
your own you don't have to guess what Your Capacity needs are you have true elasticity you seamlessly scale up or
down as needed you get much better agility as we were talking about you get
to take that scarce resource who are your software development engineers and instead of having them focus on the
undifferentiated heavy lifting of infrastructure R which matters but hardly ever differentiates your business
you get to spend those resources on things that differentiate your mission and you can deploy globally in minutes
that's a great set of advantages and it's compelling and it's why so many people are moving and when we launched AWS in the
early days you had a lot of Old Guard technology companies saying there's not
really anything new here this is virtualization this has been done for a while and of course it's a a lot more
than virtualization and as customers started voting with their workloads the Old Guard technology companies said no
no you're right this is transformational the cloud is transformational what you need though is you need AWS in your own
data center you need the private Cloud that's what you want that sounds good in concept but
when you actually dig into the details the problem with it is that the private cloud has none of the benefits that I
just mentioned you don't get to trade Capital expense for variable expense it's a high fixed cost so it's not
variable costs that are lower than what you can do on your own you actually don't get elasticity as an Enterprise or
a company you don't get the same agility you have to manage it yourself and then you can't deploy globally uh in in
minutes you can't deploy globally easily at all and so there are some companies
or organizations that have regulatory reasons or who have Legacy workloads
that they just can't stomach moving to the cloud where they're not going to use the public Cloud but I would argue that
number of organizations over time is Tiny if you're not using the public
cloud or planning on using the public cloud in some significant fashion you're at a significant competitive
disadvantage and when we talk to Enterprises about that they understand that and they it
makes sense to them conceptually but then they get worried they say wait a second does that mean I have this binary
choice where I either have to do everything in AWS or everything in my
own private cloud and no that's not a binary choice we understand the
Enterprises have a number of on premise data centers that they're not ready to retire yet and what they really want is
they want the ability to use their on-premise data centers easily with AWS

Oracle Enterprise Manager 11g environments and Dev test on AWS galada chemicals which is an

that's built a social application that has more readership than its newspaper or PBS that runs video streaming

accommodation business and website on AWS called huru or Outback Steakhouse
that runs all their advertising and marketing campaigns on top of AWS Dev test and all together new workloads are
the work are really the workloads that you see Enterprises moving fastest then there's a third strategy and a fourth

taking applications that are on premise and then supplementing them with Cloud

batch processing areas and here are a few examples so
NASDAQ has a number of market operations applications and they built these you
know well before AWS got rolling but they want to do a lot of analysis during
the day and they don't want to have to do it on premise so they these applications do a lot of analysis in the

that analysis in those applications or Nokia has a very large mobile business

service and they're running queries now that finish twice as quickly at half the
cost where sunow which is one of the largest solar power providers in the
world they have applications that they've built to be able to fail over in a disaster recovery scenario in less
than two hours to AWS so you see a a lot of on premise applications that are
being supplemented by what's available in the cloud you also see in the fourth strategy the reverse of that which are
applications that have been built in the cloud that reach back to on premise for
resources so Samsung has built a Smart Hub application on top of AWS but they
really want the transaction the financial transaction to happen on their on premise transaction system so when
customers go to buy content they get moved over seamlessly to the on premise transaction system they complete
the transaction and then they move back to the on AWS version of the application
so you see it going both ways the fifth strategy is
migration and this is a strategy that requires a little bit more thinking a
little bit more planning but over the last 14 months we have seen an explosive amount of of Enterprise migration to the
cloud and so couple examples Unilever has over 1,000 websites running on AWS
500 of which they've migrated and so they've built a pattern and a template to migrate websites quickly to the cloud
and with these websites that are now deployed in the cloud they can deploy now in two days instead of two weeks or
Bristol Meyers squid they migrated their clinical trial simulations to AWS and
they now have have hundreds and thousands of data analysts tuning these algorithms for these

and then the sixth strategy is the all-in strategy where typically a CEO or
a CIO or a CTO top down drives the organization to
move everything to the cloud and the case we talk a lot about is Netflix a
few years ago Reed Hastings decided that he didn't want to have to keep being world class and running the

application streaming service for any device and what it allows you to do is
it allows you to build whatever the app is that you want to stream you stream it from the cloud and app stream to any

the quality is that high and the way it works is that appstream uses Amazon e2's
newest instance family the G2 instance which are very powerful gpus which means that the it eliminates
the constraint of end users having less capable hardware and machines and appstream will look

right capacity that you'll need so it can scale up when there's more demand and it provides a consistent
streaming experience now as part of this effort the team built a protocol called Amazon STX and that protocol is
optimized for video encoding and consistent video playback and so part of
